channel.title: Java Bug System
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [JDK-7026262] HttpServer: improve handling of finished HTTP exchanges

item.summary: HttpServer: improve handling of finished HTTP exchanges

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Fix request (17u):
Requesting backport of this HTTP Server fix. Tested without regressions in SAP nightlies.

A pull request was submitted for review.
Branch: master
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk17u-dev/pull/2782
Date: 2024-08-03 04:23:06 +0000

Changeset: a5ffa079
Author: Daniel Jeliński <djelinski@openjdk.org>
Date: 2023-03-27 05:22:45 +0000
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk/commit/a5ffa079a0d6107be652bc026f5c91b7dcd791f8

A pull request was submitted for review.
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk/pull/13157
Date: 2023-03-23 11:33:32 +0000

Once the WriteFinishedEvent is sent, Exchange no longer owns the connection and should not try to close it.

WriteFinishedEvent constructor sets ExchangeImpl.writefinished; I added a check for writefinished in exception handlers in ServerImpl.Exchange.run; got an interesting exception in return:

 sun.net.httpserver.StreamClosedException
  at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.FixedLengthOutputStream.write(FixedLengthOutputStream.java:75)
  at java.base/java.io.FilterOutputStream.write(FilterOutputStream.java:110)
  at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.PlaceholderOutputStream.write(ExchangeImpl.java:459)
  at SmokeTest$HttpEchoHandler.handle(SmokeTest.java:151)
  at jdk.httpserver/com.sun.net.httpserver.Filter$Chain.doFilter(Filter.java:98)
  at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.AuthFilter.doFilter(AuthFilter.java:82)
  at jdk.httpserver/com.sun.net.httpserver.Filter$Chain.doFilter(Filter.java:101)
  at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.ServerImpl$Exchange$LinkHandler.handle(ServerImpl.java:871)
  at jdk.httpserver/com.sun.net.httpserver.Filter$Chain.doFilter(Filter.java:98)
  at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.ServerImpl$Exchange.run(ServerImpl.java:834)
  at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1144)
  at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:642)
  at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:1623)
  Suppressed: java.lang.AssertionError
    at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.WriteFinishedEvent.<init>(WriteFinishedEvent.java:31)
    at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.FixedLengthOutputStream.close(FixedLengthOutputStream.java:102)
    at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.PlaceholderOutputStream.close(ExchangeImpl.java:474)
    at SmokeTest$HttpEchoHandler.handle(SmokeTest.java:144)

Will see what else I can find.

Although I couldn't reproduce the race condition/failure so far in my local testing, I did capture the IOException that gets thrown by the server when this test runs (updated my local JDK code to print the stacktrace):

Jul 11, 2022 5:26:59 PM sun.net.httpserver.ServerImpl$Exchange run
INFO: ServerImpl.Exchange (1)
java.io.IOException: headers already sent
at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.ExchangeImpl.sendResponseHeaders(ExchangeImpl.java:206)
at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.HttpExchangeImpl.sendResponseHeaders(HttpExchangeImpl.java:85)
at B5017051$MyHandler2.handle(B5017051.java:188)
at jdk.httpserver/com.sun.net.httpserver.Filter$Chain.doFilter(Filter.java:98)
at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.AuthFilter.doFilter(AuthFilter.java:71)
at jdk.httpserver/com.sun.net.httpserver.Filter$Chain.doFilter(Filter.java:101)
at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.ServerImpl$Exchange$LinkHandler.handle(ServerImpl.java:752)
at jdk.httpserver/com.sun.net.httpserver.Filter$Chain.doFilter(Filter.java:98)
at jdk.httpserver/sun.net.httpserver.ServerImpl$Exchange.run(ServerImpl.java:718)
at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1144)
at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:642)
at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:1589)

(the test continues to pass with this exception being logged)

I haven't yet reviewed the test to see if it intentionally triggers some code which throws this Exception.

Looking at the code of ServerImpl, I think this is a genuine bug in the server code (and is a race condition).

One of the instances when a connection gets added to the idleConnections collection is when a "WriteFinishedEvent" is handled/processed by the Dispatcher thread (let's call the thread T1). A WriteFinishedEvent will be generated during the processing of a request by the thread that handles the request. In this specific test, we use an executor service configured for the server. So the thread handling these requests will be a different thread than T1. Let's call this thread T2. One such occasion where the WriteFinishedEvent gets generated and made available to T1, from T2, is when response headers are written out (i.e. when HttpExchange.sendResponseHeaders() is called). When this call happens, the event will be added to a collection and the T1 thread which potentially is in a blocked "select" will be woken up. During this time, after the call to sendResponseHeaders() is done and some other code is being processed, it's possible that T2 (for some reason) runs into a IOException which gets caught in the ServerImpl (line 721 https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/master/src/jdk.httpserver/share/classes/sun/net/httpserver/ServerImpl.java#L721). This then leads to a closeConnection call in T2 for a request which was currently being processed, so connection state would be State.RESPONSE. T2 in its closeConnection would then close the connection, remove it from the "rspConnections". And given the state management of connections, you wouldn't expect this connection to be in any of the other 2 collections - "idleConnections" or "reqConnections" (hence those asserts). However, when this closeConnection is in progress, it's likely that T1 (the Dispatcher thread) has noticed that WriteFinishedEvent and has started processing that event, which involves changing the state of the connection (handleEvent method) as well as adding it to the idleConnections collection (reRegister method). This is where the race resides and if T1 ends up adding the connection back into the idleConnections, then T2 will possibly see this when it is executing that assert and will thus fail.

The missing piece to all this is that the test run doesn't show the IOException that triggered all of this, since that is logged at TRACE level which isn't enabled by this test run. However, even without looking at that IOException, reading through the current code, it's possible to theorize this race condition.
JDK-8266761 was fixed in 17 and we spotted a failure in 18, so this is not a duplicate of JDK-8266761.

BT2:EVALUATION

Fails when run the assertions enabled, in sun.net.httpserver.ServerImpl.closeConnection(ServerImpl.java:467)

    451 private void closeConnection(HttpConnection conn) {
    452 conn.close();
    453 allConnections.remove(conn);
    454 switch (conn.getState()) {
    455 case REQUEST:
    456 reqConnections.remove(conn);
    457 break;
    458 case RESPONSE:
    459 rspConnections.remove(conn);
    460 break;
    461 case IDLE:
    462 idleConnections.remove(conn);
    463 break;
    464 }
    465 assert !reqConnections.remove(conn);
    466 assert !rspConnections.remove(conn); //<<<<<<<<<<< HERE
    467 assert !idleConnections.remove(conn);
    468 }


This looks a little strange. The asserts should probably use contains rather than potentially changing the behavior. Anyway, it looks like a connection is in the idleConnections when it is not expected, i.e. the state is out of sync with the set?
